author: Special Correspondent
text:
Citing the extreme temperatures in April and May when the Assembly elections are likely to be scheduled, the Trinamool Congress wants the polls advanced in West Bengal.

Party’s vice-president and one key election managers, Mukul Roy on Wednesday met Chief Electoral Officer Sunil Gupta and raised the demand.

“Voters along with election officials will face a lot of difficulty if the elections are held in May”, Mr. Roy told journalists.

The Opposition parties, particularly the Congress and the Left parties, feel that the ruling party’s proposal to advance the dates reflected that it was not confident of dealing with the “democratic and secular” forces joining hands against the ruling party.

Meanwhile, a seven-member Congress delegation led by party president Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury met the full Bench of the Election Commission in New Delhi on Wednesday.

“We have demanded that Central forces be deployed in the State ahead of polls. We have urged the Commission that elections in Bengal should be held similar to the Bihar model,” Mr. Chowdhury said.

The Congress leaders also raised questions on the law and order situation in the State.

Senior Trinamool leader and Education Minister Partha Chaterjee shot back saying, “Law and order is a state subject, not a subject of the Union Home Ministry.”

The party cited extreme heat in April and May

as the reason

for its demand
title: TMC wants Assembly elections advanced
